abstract: Peter Cichuniec and Jeremy Cooper were convicted of criminally negligent homicide, but the jury split on the assault charges, in an unusual prosecution of medical personnel.
lead_paragraph: Two Colorado paramedics were convicted of criminally negligent homicide in the 2019 death of Elijah McClain, a young unarmed Black man whose case drew national attention and forced public safety reforms in the city where he lived and died.
headline: Paramedics Found Guilty in Last Trial in Elijah McClain Death
keywords: McClain, Elijah (d 2019);Emergency Medical Treatment;Colorado;Aurora (Colo);Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings;Cichuniec, Peter;Cooper, Jeremy (Aurora, Colo, Paramedic);Black Lives Matter Movement;Ketamine (Drug);Decisions and Verdicts;Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides

abstract: After a week of heated negotiations, the U.N. Security Council approved a measure that called on Israel and Hamas to pause the fighting to allow for the delivery of more humanitarian aid.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council on Friday adopted a resolution that would allow more aid to reach desperate civilians in the Gaza Strip, ending nearly a week of intense diplomatic wrangling intended to prevent the United States from blocking the measure. But the resolution stopped short of past attempts to impose a cease-fire.
headline: U.N. Passes Resolution on Gaza Aid but Does Not Call for ‘Suspension of Hostilities’
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Israel;Defense and Military Forces;Humanitarian Aid;Gaza Strip;Palestinians;Civilian Casualties;Hamas;Terrorism;Kidnapping and Hostages;Peace Process;Security Council (UN);International Relations;United States International Relations

abstract: Will Nediger glides in with a slippery, imposing themeless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Take the diagonal steps of entries we have solved in recent puzzles, add triple stacks of blistering originality to the top and bottom and you’ve got this daunting challenge from Will Nediger, a veteran weekend constructor who can be counted on for just this type of thing.
headline: Not What You’d Expect
keywords: Crossword Puzzles;Nediger, Will (Crossword Constructor)

abstract: For couples looking to recreate a Hallmark Christmas movie setting, the Historic Hotel Bethlehem has become a popular destination for holiday nuptials.

abstract: Record numbers of legal immigrants came to Britain from outside the E.U. in recent years. Some on the right call that a “Brexit betrayal.”
lead_paragraph: Inflammatory warnings from politicians. Knife-edge votes in Parliament. A looming election against a backdrop of national crisis. Britain’s ruling Conservative Party has been caught up in a clamorous debate over deporting asylum seekers to Rwanda, which has at times sounded like a not-so-distant echo of Brexit.
headline: Brexiteers Vowed to ‘Take Back Control’ of U.K. Borders. What Happened?
keywords: Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit);Politics and Government;Illegal Immigration;Asylum, Right of;Immigration and Emigration;Refugees and Displaced Persons

abstract: The case was initially seen as an illustration of the city’s crime and homelessness woes. Further evidence challenged that narrative.
lead_paragraph: A homeless man who beat a former San Francisco city official with a metal pipe was found not guilty of assault charges on Friday, capping a case that had drawn national attention as a symbol of the city’s crime and homelessness problems until a public defender unearthed a surprising back story.
headline: Jurors Find San Francisco Homeless Man Not Guilty in Pipe Beating
keywords: Homeless Persons;Assaults;Self-Defense;San Francisco (Calif)

abstract: Knitting scarves, sweaters and other presents can take a lot of time, money and energy. But there can also be a deeper cost: hurt feelings.
lead_paragraph: Cydney Alvarez, a fabric developer in Brooklyn, was packing to visit her family in Dallas for Christmas last year when she realized she had knitted her stepmother two left-handed mittens. She rushed to replace one: “I was frantically trying to finish it on the flight,” she said.
headline: The Emotional Gamble of a Hand-Knitted Gift
keywords: Knitting and Knit Goods;Handicrafts;Gifts;Wool and Woolen Goods

abstract: Domestic shootings are a small portion of the city’s violence, but victims’ advocates say the new spike is worrisome.
lead_paragraph: Chicago is expected to end 2023 with a double-digit decline in both shootings and homicides, a sign that the pandemic-era rise in gun violence is beginning to recede. But citywide data shows that a small subset of Chicago’s shootings — those involving domestic violence — have accelerated this year, a spike that is prompting new alarm among advocates for victims.
headline: Shootings Dip in Chicago but Grow in Domestic Violence Cases
keywords: Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Domestic Violence;Firearms;Chicago (Ill)

abstract: Four new books look to fauna to get us through tough times.
lead_paragraph: In a recent essay, the writer and environmental activist Terry Tempest Williams, reflecting on the perils of climate change, wrote, “Before we can save this world we are losing, we must first learn how to savor what remains.” To savor something is to know you will lose it, and to cherish it all the more for that knowledge.
headline: Animal Magnetism — and Optimism

abstract: The country is moving to curb the industry’s punishing work hours. But that could leave a shortfall that disrupts Japan’s entire logistics system.
lead_paragraph: It was dark when Daiki Funamizu pulled his truck into the market in Osaka, ending a 15-hour haul down Japan’s main island. He rubbed his sore back and wiped the sweat off his forehead. Then he began several more hours of work to unload 500 boxes of red apples.
headline: How a Crisis in Truck Driving Could Change Life in Japan
keywords: Trucks and Trucking;Work-Life Balance;Shortages;Working Hours;Delivery Services;Overtime;Freight (Cargo);Japan;vis-photo;Regulation and Deregulation of Industry;Supply Chain

abstract: An archaeological expedition in Mexico seeks what’s left of the sprawling, centuries-old catacombs hidden below the ruins of Mitla.
lead_paragraph: The ruins of Mitla sit about 30 miles from Oaxaca in the mountains of southern Mexico, built on a high valley floor as a gateway between the world of the living and the dead. The site was established in roughly A.D. 200  as a fortified village, and then as a burial ground by the Zapotecs, the so-called Cloud People, who settled in the region around 1500 B.C.
headline: What Lies Beneath the Vatican of the Zapotecs?
keywords: Oaxaca (Mexico);Archaeology and Anthropology;Historic Buildings and Sites;Churches (Buildings);Tombs and Tombstones;Christians and Christianity;Religion and Belief;your-feed-science

abstract: Lawmakers approved $5 billion for states to build a network of fast chargers two years ago. Although some states have made progress in recent weeks, most have not yet awarded contracts or started construction.
lead_paragraph: More than two years ago, lawmakers approved billions of dollars to build out a national electric vehicle charging network in the hopes of encouraging more drivers to switch to cleaner cars. The money, included in the bipartisan infrastructure law, was intended to help assure drivers they could reliably travel longer distances without running out of power.
headline: Slow Rollout of National Charging System Could Hinder E.V. Adoption
keywords: Electric and Hybrid Vehicles;Automobile Service and Charging Stations;Automobiles;States (US);Infrastructure (Public Works);Transportation Department (US);United States Politics and Government;New York State;Ohio;United States

abstract: Every year, the agency tries to claw back billions in overpaid benefits — including from children who are unaware their parents collected money on their behalf.
lead_paragraph: Kree Flowers had recently gotten married and decided to log into her account on the Social Security Administration’s website in February to check on the status of her retirement benefits. She was shocked to see a big red number at the top of the page. According to the agency, she had been overpaid by $17,121.21.
headline: When Social Security Becomes a Debt Collector
keywords: Social Security (US);Debt Collection;Personal Finances;Social Security Administration;Disability Insurance;Workers' Compensation Insurance;United States Politics and Government

abstract: In 2024, more low-balance, forgotten 401(k)s and similar retirement plans could be forced into rollover accounts, which don’t benefit their owners. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: As a Comerica Bank executive with more than 35 years of experience in wealth management, Lisa Featherngill knows how to handle retirement money. But when she left her previous position at Wells Fargo two years ago, she had to figure out what to do with her old 401(k) — and was as flummoxed as any other person changing jobs.

abstract: Our favorite images from the year.
lead_paragraph: Styles is with people: how they dress, how they live, how they navigate our dynamic world. As such, we are engrossed in looking closely. This year’s collection of images reflects those fixations, whether in a cropped shot of Gwyneth Paltrow’s bare face, or in the swirling memorial for a dancer at a Brooklyn gas station. Each photograph in this roundup gives readers unfettered insight into the characters and places that commanded our gazes.

abstract: The boards have broad discretion to carry out their duties in the best interest of shareholders. But they cannot discriminate.
lead_paragraph: Q: I have tried to sell my co-op apartment in Jackson Heights, Queens, several times, but the board never accepts the prospective buyer. I lost a sale when the board said the co-op’s financial information wasn’t available because the building was being audited. I lost another when the board said the buyer’s income was too low. And once I had a cash buyer who was going to live alone, without any pets, and they still turned him down. I fear the board is discriminating against my prospective buyers on the basis of race, or retaliating against me because I have called 311 several times. What can I do?
headline: My Co-op Board Is Preventing Me From Selling My Apartment
keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Cooperatives;Discrimination;Three-One-One (311) (NYC Hot Line);Content Type: Service;New York City

abstract: Javier Milei warned that things would get worse before they got better. Now Argentines are living it.

abstract: Your very specific, highly idiosyncratic best-ofs of the year.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month I asked you to send along your highly specific personal best-of list for 2023. I requested lists not limited to the usual categories like “best movie” or “best book” but that included, say, the best walk you took, or the best idea you had, or the best change you made to your routine. As I considered my own year, compiling my favorite cultural artifacts and foods and experiences, anything I found I was enjoying became a candidate for the list. Take George Winston’s 1982 album “December.” I listened to it for the first time in decades on Thursday, in honor of the winter solstice, and, I thought, “Is this the best nostalgic relistening experience I had this year?” Why not? The beauty of the personal best-of list is its categories are endless, its inventory selected by a jury of one.
headline: The Morning Readers’ Favorite Things of 2023
keywords: internal-storyline-no;Television;Movies;Books and Literature;Christmas;New Year;Holidays and Special Occasions

abstract: If admitted liars like Rudy Giuliani can avoid having to pay up, what does accountability even look like now?
lead_paragraph: No sooner did a jury deliver a nearly $150 million defamation judgment against the former New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani than he went out and again started smearing the two Georgia election workers at the center of the case. Within days, he filed for bankruptcy, shielding himself in the near term from having to surrender whatever assets he has to his creditors.
headline: The Unsettling Truth at the Heart of the Giuliani Case
keywords: Compensation for Damages (Law);Libel and Slander;Decisions and Verdicts;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Presidential Election of 2020;Rumors and Misinformation;Giuliani, Rudolph W;Jones, Alex (1974- );Trump, Donald J;Georgia

abstract: We should accept our cultural inheritance as we find it.

keywords: Messiah (Musical Work);Handel, George Frederick;Classical Music;Christians and Christianity;Christmas

abstract: Labor unrest has reached the Church of England.
lead_paragraph: On a blustery December morning, the Rev. Nicky Skipworth is leading her congregation in prayer. But the word of God is not being delivered from the pulpit of the parish church in Harworth, a village outside Doncaster, England. It costs the church 200 pounds, or $255, to heat a midweek service. To save funds, it has been moved to the local sports center.
headline: It’s Christmas, and England’s Priests Have Had Enough
keywords: Church of England;Anglican Churches;Clergy;Great Britain;Organized Labor;Wages and Salaries;Christians and Christianity

abstract: Steven Spielberg’s “Munich” was considered by many to be a flop in 2005. But its examination of the moral toll of vengeance couldn’t feel more relevant.
lead_paragraph: Watching movies is what I do — for decades as a film critic and for even longer than that, before and since, as a regular human. As a critic, I’m trained to study and coolly interpret the language of filmmakers. Off the clock, I watch to be diverted or to be dazzled, to be comforted or to escape, to be challenged or to try to better understand the world, filtered through someone else’s art. Sometimes this habit has helped me feel well equipped to deal with what’s going on in the world, sometimes less so.
headline: The Best Movie About Israel and Gaza Now Came Out 18 Years Ago
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Israel;Gaza Strip;Jews and Judaism;Palestinians;Movies;Munich (Movie);Spielberg, Steven

abstract: The touring business saw record revenue in 2023 and major tours made news, but fans still struggle with ticket prices and access — and political leaders are watching.
lead_paragraph: Three years after the pandemic brought live music to a halt, the touring business is thriving: 2023 brought in record revenue — over $9 billion — thanks in part to major outings by Taylor Swift and Beyoncé, and in part to increased prices across the board. Live shows are also becoming more ambitious in scale and filigree, underscoring how big concerts are becoming experiential luxury goods.
headline: Taylor Swift, Beyoncé and the Sphere: The Year in Live Music
keywords: audio-neutral-informative;Pop and Rock Music;Two Thousand Twenty Three;Ticketmaster;Knowles, Beyonce;Swift, Taylor;U2 (Music Group);Scott, Travis (1992- )

abstract: Bright because Melissa Clark adds lemon zest to the eggy custard, and merry because you can assemble it ahead of time to free up your morning.
lead_paragraph: It’s the day before the night before Christmas, and all through the house, all the creatures are stirring (but hopefully no mice to speak of). We’ll get to dinner in a moment, but first — because Christmas morning is on the brain — we want to share this spinach and Gruyère breakfast casserole, a new recipe from Melissa Clark. It’s hearty (lots of sautéed spinach and nutty Gruyère cheese), bright (Melissa, noted lemon-lover, adds zest to the eggy custard) and merry-making (you can assemble the casserole ahead of time and bake it when you’re ready, freeing up your morning for any manner of happy holiday high jinks).
headline: A Merry and Bright Cheesy Spinach Breakfast Casserole
keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks;Content Type: Service

abstract: A reporter’s columns about city life were a good fit for the Armed Services Editions, which published books for the American soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marines fighting World War II.
lead_paragraph: Newspaper columns don’t often make good anthologies. Overtaken by events, columns can lose resonance and relevance long before they reach bookstores. In its timelessness, however, “The Eight Million: Journal of a New York Correspondent,” an anthology of the work of Meyer Berger (1898-1959), poetically defies the rule.
headline: New York Stories, for the Troops
keywords: Book Trade and Publishing;Grolier Club;Newspapers

abstract: These children’s picture books have been banned. To some, the topics — racism, sexuality, transgender identity and gay relationships — are not appropriate for very young readers.
lead_paragraph: A picture book about a same-sex penguin couple at the Central Park Zoo was made inaccessible to young students in a Florida school district. The history of the Gay Pride flag was one of the most widely banned books in the country. An illustrated story about surviving slavery in America was prohibited in classrooms.
headline: Are These Topics Too Adult for the Youngest Readers? Take a Look.

abstract: A report by the Board of Correction found that eight people remained in their cells for a half-hour while smoke spread through a housing unit.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 30 minutes in April, Rikers Island staff members kept eight people locked in their cells while the workers tried to extinguish a fire and smoke spread through a housing unit, according to a report from the city’s Board of Correction.
headline: Rikers Detainees Were Kept Locked in Cells After Fire Broke Out
keywords: Rikers Island Prison Complex;Fires and Firefighters;Prisons and Prisoners;Prison Guards and Corrections Officers;Correction Department (NYC);Legal Aid Society;Maginley-Liddie, Lynelle

abstract: Andrew Royer involuntarily confessed to a murder in Indiana, judges ruled. Despite holes in the case, he served more than 16 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A man with developmental disabilities who spent more than 16 years in prison after being wrongfully convicted of murder has reached a settlement of $11,725,000 with the city of Elkhart, Ind., his lawyers said on Friday.
headline: Man With Developmental Disabilities Settles Wrongful Conviction Suit for $11.7 Million
keywords: Elkhart (Ind);False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments;Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings;Confessions;Perjury;Decisions and Verdicts;Compensation for Damages (Law);Suits and Litigation (Civil);Disabilities

abstract: An artist of many mediums, he used a vast array of materials, including stone, paint, piles of earth and even lettuce, to provoke thought and wonder.
lead_paragraph: Giovanni Anselmo, one of the funnier and more philosophical of the Italian artists making what the critic Germano Celant indelibly named Arte Povera, or “poor art,” died on Monday at his home in Turin, Italy. He was 89.
headline: Giovanni Anselmo, a Leader of the Arte Povera Movement, Dies at 89
keywords: Anselmo, Giovanni;Deaths (Obituaries);Sculpture;Art;Goodman, Marian, Gallery (Manhattan, NY);Italy

abstract: The Security Council resolution, watered down to avoid a U.S. veto, directs urgent action to increase aid, but does not call for a cease-fire that would make it safe to distribute the aid.
lead_paragraph: United Nations and other aid officials warned on Saturday that a new U.N. Security Council resolution calling for stepped-up aid delivery to the increasingly hungry and sick civilians of the Gaza Strip would fail to stop the spiraling humanitarian crisis because it did not demand a full halt to the fighting.
headline: Without a Truce, U.N. Resolution May Do Little for Gaza, Aid Groups Say

abstract: DealBook lists its favorite podcasts and books for getting smarter about business and the economy.

abstract: When Brazilian musicians fused samba with jazz and classical influences in the 1950s and ’60s, he was among the first, and the best.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Lyra, a Brazilian composer, singer and guitarist whose cool, meticulous melodies helped give structure and power to bossa nova, the samba-inflected jazz style that became a worldwide phenomenon in the early 1960s, died on Dec. 16 in Rio de Janeiro. He was 90.
headline: Carlos Lyra, Composer Who Brought Finesse to Bossa Nova, Dies at 90
